contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=September 2010}} [[File:NauruBuada.png|thumb|200px|right|Buada district shown within Nauru.]] '''Buada''' is a [[Districts of Nauru|district]] in the [[Pacific]] nation of [[Nauru]]. It is the only district in [[Buada Constituency]]. The only landlocked district in the Republic of Nauru, it is in the southwestern part of the island, and covers the central [[Buada Lagoon]]. Buada is a fertile piece in Nauru and mostly wet and tropical due to the mass vegetation (compared to the rest of the island). It covers an area of 2.6 kmÂ², which in comparison with other of Nauru's districts, makes it among the largest. Buada district has a population of 980. Buada has retained more vegetation than other districts, where, because of mining, much vegetation has been lost. The proximity of the Buada Lagoon has been relevant to the survival of vegetation. [[Ruben Kun]], who represented Buada in the [[Parliament of Nauru]], served as [[President of Nauru]] from 1996 to 1997. Honorable Mr Roland Kun (son of Ruben Kun) is the current (2012) representative for Buada district to the Parliarment of Nauru. ancient name Arenibok(as early as 1500s to the late 1800s) Germans refer to it as 'Bush Village'(1889) after agreeing to its new boundaries located by the Germans, the lacols during 1890 named it Buada (ghost land) which is still referred to nowadays. The last of the few Irutsi clans consisting of four members only, along with the largest of all clans, the Eamwit, inhabited Buada ever since it was known by its original name Arenibok. Few of the other two clans namely the Emea and the Deiboe clans also resided with their relatives in Buada the 10 Year Tribal War 1st began in this district during a wedding festival in Aujo hamlet where a drunk white open fired and accidentally killed the lad Giubu of the proud Eamwit clan, nephew of chief Teiauw of the Eaoru clan and a greatnephew of the highly respected chief Aremwa. Arenibok (now Buada) had four main villages namely Arenibok and Redeto, villages on the banks of the great Arenibok Sea(now Buada Lagoon) and two other villages of Noreo on the steep slopes towards the south and Aujo with its few hamlets towards inland to the north. {{Districts of Nauru}} {{Coord|0|32|S|166|55|E|display=title}} [[Category:Districts of Nauru]] {{Nauru-geo-stub}}
